description:
Wise Sons was looking very appealing as they were carving slabs of meat on the spot. I was intrigued since I was already in the mood for a sandwich, just not any 'ol plain sandwich though.

$15.50 Corned Beef Reuben w/ Russian dressing, Swiss cheese & sauerkraut on rye:
This reuben turned out to be surprisingly small. It seemed like the guy stacking my sandwich didn't put enough corned beef in there. Now I actually don't enjoy biting into a mountain of meat, like you would get from certain popular Jewish delis. However, this sandwich really could have used more volume. It was cut in half and each half was only a few bites. Normally, I wouldn't have minded, but the price is rather steep.
As for taste, the corned beef was pretty good. The rye bread was buttery and nicely toasted. The Swiss cheese had melted a bit and the sauerkraut was only mildly acidic. It also came with a pickle.

I also wanted to try their babka, but they didn't have it at the time. Apparently they serve a truncated version of their menu here, since it is a stand at the market and they don't have their full kitchen. 
It was a good reuben. Taste was there, but for the price and the portion size, I most likely will not be returning for a sandwich. I'll give it a 7/10, but just barely.
author: Joy W.

description: Disappointed. Asked for a classic Reuben. Received disappointment. See picture. Also ordered bagels. They tasted like they were at least a day old. All around terrible experience.
author: Paul P.

description:
After years of watching wise sons from afar, and never having the time to wait in line during my lunch break, I finally was able to try it on a rogue day off. I could have gone to any of the locations, but according to other yelpers reviews the location at the Ferry Building is the best.

My friend and I split the rueben and classic with pastrami. I wouldn't quite say I was disappointed, but I wasn't blown away either. From all of the hype I was expecting it to be amazing. The pastrami itself was salty and tender. It was cooked perfectly - I loved that I was able to bite right through the sandwich (after a little jaw unhinging) without pulling it all out. The overall package (bread, sauces, etc) was a bit lacking and the pastrami was really the star of the show. I personally enjoy my ruebens a bit more saucy but could barely taste the dressing or slaw.

It's just unfortunate that all of the food in San Francisco has become relative to me and I couldn't help but wish I had gone to deli board instead.
author: Christine M.

description: Happen to be at the Ferry Building one fine afternoon. Stomach was craving a pizza. But the eyes saw the word "pastrami". Popped in line at Wise Sons and ordered a #19 (Reuben with cole slaw instead of sauerkraut). It was served surprisingly fast. But at first bite I realized why. The bread was not grilled. The cheese was straight out of the cooler (aka not melted). The meat was ok, not stacked notoriously high for a "NY" style reuben. The slaw was ok. The sandwich was just plain and not satisfying. Shoulda went with the pizza.
author: Stephen Y.

description: Bad service wait forever .. bagels did not seem to be fresh and tasteless very bad over cooked  plus very expensive one bagel and coffee eight bucks Starbucks is much cheaper so is Noah's but  there not much better either ... hard to find good places ...
author: Mark M.

description: Meh. I had a Rueben. Potato salad was normal. Turban was normal. Pickles were meh. I would not come back for the prices they charge. I love reubens and pastrami but these wise sons ain't offering anything special. You can skip and won't be disappointed.
author: Alexander H.

description: Wise Sons' runs a stand every Thursday at the farmers market in front of the ferry building. I was craving a real bagel and I found it here. It's a bit chewier than I'm used to but it certainly hit the spot. The bagel is only $4 and rather filling. It comes toasted and slathered with cream cheese. Why 4 and not 5? It was a bit too salty but other than that it had everything an everything bagel could ask for.
author: Tammy T.

description:
I tried out Wise Sons at their booth at the Ferry Plaza Farmers Market.  What really sold me was when they pulled out their freshly cured slab of pastrami.  The aroma was incredible!  After seeing and smelling that beautiful slab of pastrami, I had to get their Pastrami Sandwich.

Pastrami Sandwich -- http://bit.ly/1Eib5jS
Okay, while it may not the best pastrami sandwich I've ever had, it's a REALLY GOOD pastrami sandwich nonetheless.  Cured nicely and melts in your mouth just like the Pastrami at Katz's in NYC.  And while the sandwich may not be ginormous like Katz's, or even Miller's here in SF, it's still a generous portion that'll satisfy your hunger.

Wise Sons has definitely made a great first impression on me with their pastrami.  Now that I know what to expect, I hope to visit their other locations and try their other sandwiches.
author: Rodney H.

description: Had pastrami rueben with a smoked salmon, capers, and cream cheese everything bagel. Bagel was a little too salty.  Sandwich was good but could have been a little more spread out.   Line moved relatively quickly.
author: Michael E.

description:
I spent the first part of my post-college adult life living in Manhattan and took the amazing deli food for granted.  It wasn't until I moved to San Francisco and saw what passed as pastrami that I truly understood how good I had it.  Then came Wise Sons.  When I crave a nice hand carved pastrami or corned beef sandwich, they're the only ones I think of.  They still haven't mastered the NYC bagel yet, but I'm hoping they'll crack that case soon.

Pastrami: Best meat offering by far!  Nicely spiced exterior.  Tender, but still retains its shape.

Corned Beef: Way better than those tough, overboiled slabs you get on St. Patrick's Day!  Subtle flavor throughout.  Firm, yet tender.

Brisket: Probably the most lackluster of the meats; it's decent but you're better off ordering Pastrami or Corned Beef.

Bagel w/ Lox: Reminded me of brunching back in Manhattan, except this had higher quality cream cheese, fish and veggies/herbs.  The bagel was kind of meh, but the crunchy contrast it provided helped the experience.

Bialy w/ Lox: Like the bagel version, except without the bagel.  I enjoy a good bialy by itself, but it was too soft for an open-faced lox sandwich.  I'm not sure if their toaster was set too low or if bialys just don't toast well.

Matzoh Ball Soup: Better than at a NYC diner, but not better than at specialty delis in NYC.  The Matzoh Balls were standard. The broth was light, but still held some decent flavors.

Latkes: Generous sized potato pancakes.  They were reheated on the griddle to order, so not as crispy as one would get if made fresh right there.  The apple chutney was far superior to the apple sauce from a jar many places offer.

Potato Salad: A nice side if it comes with your meal, but I wouldn't go out of my way to order it separately.

House Pickles: Solid effort.

Chocolate Babka: So many delicious veins of chocolate flowing through this delicious dessert!  Kinda heavy, so like a meal by itself.  Or at least something to save for a 3PM coffee.
author: Adam B.

description: Really enjoyed the bagel and salmon here eaten at the ferry building by the water. Friendly service and excellent bagel!!
author: Ann D.

description:
Pastrami sandwich is of the norm and overpriced for what it is. 12 bucks per say. 

My bread that I received, wasn't toasted.  It was grainy on the outside crust, which gave it texture. 

Not much spazz, but a good ole sandwich.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Had lunch today with three friends.  I ordered the pastrami with potato salad and a coke.  Came to over $21.00....okay , I guess , in SF .  However, my pastrami was ( literally) half fat and half pastrami.  I had to remove  1/2 of each slice of pastrami ( the fat)  in the sandwich and put the meat back in between the two slices of bread.  If you order it I'd recommend that you ask for MEAT ONLY W/O FAT !   RM San Francisco
author: Bruce M.

description:
I've definitely been here a lot - especially on Tuesdays and Thursdays. They have so many different types of deli foods - pastrami, reuben, and burgers.  I've tried the burger and pastrami more than once and they've always been enjoyable. They're both pretty filling as a meal - so definitely be hungry if you're trying them. 

7x7 suggested the chocolate babka.  I had definitely wanted to get it during the year, but since the kitchen in their bakery had been burned down in the Mission fire earlier in the year, it was difficult for them to bake very much. I figured I would ask the cashier at the ferry building one Thursday to see if they had any babka - and they bring them to the ferry building, but to get there early. 

I showed up around 12:15 the next time and was able to snatch the last one! The babka is this sweet cake with this awesome crumb topping. For the price - it's a steal! So delicious, but much too heavy and large for a dessert after lunch..really at any time.  

Overall, I love this stand at the Ferry Building - definitely one of my go-tos when I go to the Ferry Building Farmer's Market 

Protip: Chocolate Babka!
author: Nina Y.

description:
Good sandwich but not enough food for the price. 

I was recently at the ferry building farmer's market and decided to stop by Wise Sons after reading the yelp reviews. You see, I'm a big fan of rubens. So that's exactly what I ordered when I arrived at the front of the line. But the friendly woman behind the counter asked if I wanted the pastrami or the corned beef.

"Whichever one you think you guys do better," I replied.

And that's how I ended up with a corned beef ruben ($12). How was it? Well the corned beef was well done and had some great flavor. Cheese was nice and oozy. The bread was decent. Maybe there were a few spots on the bread that were a bit too charred for me but overall it was a messy and delicious sandwich. It was just a bit pricey. For $12 I would've expected them to pile on a little more corned beef.  

Oh well. 

But the food was indeed good and I am willing to give them another go. Maybe I'll be back to get the corned beef on rye. I just saw a picture that another yelper posted and it looked pretty substantial. Until then, I'm leaving them with 3 stars.
author: John B.

description:
You can have Tuesdays with Morrie since the Wise Sons show up with their pop-up at the Ferry Building every week out front (photo: http://bit.ly/1df8CtA). Although they look like they have a full crew, it's not the complete menu they serve, just a couple of their signature sandwiches, a few sides and something sweet, but the combination is apparently enough to draw quite a crowd (photo: http://bit.ly/1ehiC44). I had been to the one at the Contemporary Jewish Museum to see what the hype was about at the 24th Street location, and I certainly liked it enough to give this one a go for a rare lunch outdoors. But I have to mention that the thing that drew me was not the sandwich. It was the $3.50 slice of Noodle Kugel (photo: http://bit.ly/1cY2CBX). Yes, noodle kugel.

Who would think a non-Kosher Asian curmudgeon like myself would ever dream about noodle kugel? And what's not to love about noodle kugel? Egg noodles, golden raisins, sugar, cinnamon, crusty topping. Oy. Well played, Wise Sons. That was a decadent treat to have between work meetings on a park bench with a hostile homeless guy staring at me. But wait, there's more. I also ordered a $11 Roast Beef Sandwich which was not so special (photo: http://bit.ly/1g9qbvx). It was on their specials menu and quite dry even with the special mayo they slathered on the bread. The $2.50 serving of Potato Salad was surprisingly meh as chock full of chopped vegetables as it was (photo: http://bit.ly/1ehivFA). But maybe I should come back for the noodle kugel. It's not a regular item they carry, so Morrie, you may have to wait.

FOOD - 3 stars...kinda meh compared to their other operation but oh that noodle kugel
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...it's a pop-up...what d'ya expect? white tablecloths and violins?
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...they're goin' as fast as they can
TOTAL - 3 stars...a kugel does not a stellar lunch make...you should pardon the expression
author: Ed U.

description:
two words: chocolate babka.

another two words: get it.

a few thoughts: available at their Ferry Building outpost during the week in the event you can't make it out to their Mission shop.  although, having this fresh and hot would probably make me cry.  a few tears for the amount of exercise I'll need to do, but more tears for how happy I am and how the world makes so much sense when you swirl chocolate in delicious sweet bread.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Let Me Start This Review By Stating The Obvious Yelp Never Ever Allows You To Not Give A Star Because If That Option Was Available I Would Not Be Issuing One.

On To The Review.... A Friend & I Decide To Go Here For Lunch In The Mood For Pastrami We Get There Line Is Short, Friendly Lady Taking Orders And The Food Was Fast So Far So Good.... 

As We Walk Away With Our Taste Buds Jumping We Open Up The Eco Friendly Box The Sandwich Was Placed In And To Our Dismay We Both Looked At Eachother & said Ewwwww What Is That? We Came To  The Conclusion That It Was Corned Beef So We Casually Walk Back To The Counter and Advise of What We Thought Was The Wrong Sandwich But Sadly It Wasnt.... it was "Pastrami ". I have NEVER EVER Seen Pastrami That Looked Like Over Cooked Blubber It Was So Bad We Gave It Away......

The $13.00 You Shell Out For Fat Is Not Worth It So Save Your Dough. 

I have included a picture of what a Real Pastrami Sandwich Should Look Like.
author: Ibedatnica I.

description:
So so solid. I've been meaning to try this for a long time. Its never been very convenient, but thank goodness, working on Christmas Eve day when I don't have to work. Mission completed. 
The pastrami sandwich is nothing short of amazing. I was sad after finding out Moishe's Pippic shut down but at least these guys can hold it down.This is nothing short of the best of it's kind in SF. The competition can even come close. 
Did I mention the potato salad, Just not funny. This its some real serious business. Thank you and good job.

I will have to come back and try the rest sometime.
author: Ben M.

description: That is a damn good $10 bagel and smoked salmon. Crispy on the outside, chewy inside, creamy cream cheese, HIGH quality salmon, capers, and onions........ Heaven. I only wish it was bigger!
author: Jen B.

description:
$14 for a combo Reuban (corned beef w/ pastrami) and it was worth it. The meat was well-seasoned and smokey - top quality. Texture was beautiful - juicy, silky meat nestled between 2 pieces of toasted bread. Acidity from the pickles help to counterbalance the richness.

This is a stand in front of the Ferry building. Don't make the same mistake I did and go inside the building itself to search for it.
author: Julie L.

description:
What an amazing treat it was to find food stalls at the Tuesday Farmers Market place. Even better, Wise Sons Delicatessen! Now keep in mind, my first time experience at their Mission restaurant was less than satisying but I knew there was hope, I simply had to order the right thing. 

Well, would you know it, the answer was right in front of me, I was just too blind to see. If I had ordered the pastrami sandwich the first time, I'm certain my experience would have been much different. 

Is there anything better than a heaping pile of tender, savory layers of pastrami nestled between two slices of rye bread with a gentle hint of the pickling brine.

Overall Thoughts

All I can say is I am thankfully that I have a place to go to when I am in a need for a Jewish fix
author: Eddie W.

description: They're located at the Tuesday and Thursday Farmer's market just outside the Ferry building, so if I'm ever looking for lunch on one of those days, Wise Sons is my go-to spot. I've only had the open lox, which is: cream cheese, lox, capers, an onions atop two halves of a bagel. The smoked salmon is so fresh, and the 'everything' bagel has a nice crunch to it. Would definitely recommend this as one of the better lox bagels I've had; the only downside is that it's $10 for lox and $13 for open lox, pretty pricey.
author: Celia K.

description:
Challah bread bun?! Challah, back!!!

The texture of the Challah bread bun plus dream cheese plus pastrami with chili dream sauce...I don't know if I fouled have asked for more. 

When I was debating between two sandwiches as the register, the guy said....well, if you want something unforgettable,: you should go with the shleppy Joe. Definitely true. 

And just enough pickles to match, too.
author: Annie S.

description:
Ordered a pastrami sandwich a cole slaw.  The pastrami meaty, fatty, salty and tender.  I loved the side of crunchy pickles.  

Didn't like the coleslaw, there was too much mayonnaise and it tasted a bit funny - somewhat bitter and sour (but not vinegar sour) - threw it out because I'm afraid it has gone bad.
author: Stacy D.

description:
This fell into the "just ok" category for me. The guys were quite friendly but the food failed to live up to the hype I'd imposed on it.

We tried a corned beef Reuben and a pastrami sandwich. Make sure to grab mustard if you want it! I'd requested it but it didn't end up on either sandwich. I was surprised to find the pastrami unoptimally carved, in my opinion, leading it to be really chewy. Additionally the flavor was too smoky for my taste. I preferred the corned beef and the Reuben was fine, but not synergistically delicious like it should be. I did like the pickles though!
author: Lisa K.

description:
I've tried just about everything on the menu here and based on my experiences here I'd say that anything that has pastrami in it will be your best bet. They change the menu slightly each time but the standouts for me have been the pastrami sandwiches or their ever changing daily burger special.  The potato salad is my side dish choice since they use red potatoes and it has a creamy but not mushy texture. To the left of the register you should help yourself to some deli mustard which gives all their sandwiches a good kick. If your still on the fence then drop by and watch them cut the pastrami/brisket. A little pricey but consistently worth it. I'll be back next tuesday If you want to split a chocolate bakclava! 


Ferry Plaza location only open on Tuesdays. Arrive before 11:30am or else expect there to be a line as it is with most of the stalls during the Tuesday lunch rush.
author: Norris T.

description:
My friends and I had a break between classes so we decided to see what's out at the Farmer's Market by the ferry buildings. 

We were actually hoping for a specific truck, but we settled for Wise Son's Delicatessen. Oh man, I'm SO glad we decided to get food from here! 

The menu is pretty small, but you'll find that you won't know what to order because a lot of it sounds really good. I didn't know what some of the things were so I asked the cashier. He was very friendly and helpful--they're all actually very fun and nice! After all was said and done, I decided to order the grilled corned beef Reuben, a slice of chocolate babka, and a black cherry soda. They have a huge jug of grainy mustard (my favorite!) too so I took advantage of that.

I never knew Jewish food was so good! The sandwich was made perfectly and it had the highest quality of ingredients I have ever had. They make everything themselves and you can see them chopping up the corned beef in the back of the tent. The sandwiches come with a pickle. I don't even like pickles, but I found that I actually liked it. 

The chocolate babka was great too! I honestly didn't know what to expect because I didn't even know what a babka really was but it's...amazing. Don't get it if you don't like chocolate though because it's very rich in chocolate swirls. 

I was definitely happy with my lunch that day. Must try!
author: Sofia R.

description:
Was craving smoked salmon on top of a bagel and was lucky that the farmers market was still open. Theirs is good..would have liked more salmon though. I was still hungry afterwards :3

Their pastrami sandwich though is fucking delicious!!! My boyfriend hardly ever orders sandwiches but loved this. They give you a decent  amount of tender, flavorful meat between two slices of toasted rye, nom. He ate it as is but I loooved it with the mustard.

It was a little expensive for just a sandwich (would be more justified if there were more meat or came with a side) but we would still order it again.
author: Melissa C.

description: I often see reviews of SF bagel places with "xyz place is not as good as my favorite place in NYC." I can't say whether Wise Sons makes the best bagels or even a great bagel relative to whatever the gold standard for bagels is supposed to be. But, I'm certain that they make the best bagel I've tasted in this city.
author: Drew C.

description:
Softy.

Bit derogatory: http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=softy

Bit brilliant: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/14/bialy-bialys-bagel_n_4782763.html.

Especially with lox, capers, cream cheese and pickles on the side. Full of flavor with a soft and chewy texture truly unlike traditional bagels. As good as it should be for $10.

Don't fight the urge to try one.
author: Jason B.

description:
Wise Sons has what has to be one of the best Reuben's I've had in SF.

The bread is grilled (not toasted) perfectly...the pastrami, lean and well seasoned. They don't overdo it with the thousand island dressing. My only complaint? I wish it came with a little more pickle on the side.

When I occasionally eat at the ferry building on Tuesdays or Thursdays (when the restaurants set up), I look for Wise Sons first...
author: Aaron M.

description:
There is no shortage of lunch options at the Ferry Building, especially on Farmers' market days (Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays).  Trying most every vendor at the market, this was the only that I've yet to try until Tuesday.  Taking a shopping break, I stopped and studied their menu and remembered that I haven't had a reuben sandwich since... well, remember when there was a Max's Diner on 3rd Street near Folsom?  Yes, THAT LONG!
The one that caught my eye was the turkey reuben sandwich (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), which comes with a pickle.  At around $10.00, it certainly isn't a bargain, but what, in Ferry Building's name, is inexpensive there?!  The flavor was very good, less salty than regular pastrami.  
This was a nice preview for Thanksgiving, having turkey pastrami instead of the regular one.  If you have a craving for a reuben, this is probably a healthier version and, guess what... it's just as tasty.
author: Mike C.

description:
Two months after putting Wise Sons on my "to do" list, I finally decided that this Saturday was it, time to check out the babka in honor of my moms' (plural) visit to San Francisco. 

Highlights:
The pickle plate was amazing, super fresh. The pickled beets were probably my favorite. The pickles were good, especially the ones in the cup with almost a 1:2 cucumber:dill ratio.
The chocolate babka was moist and had just enough chocolate for the bread to still qualify for a breakfast food. 
Great fresh lox on the bagel
Amazing rye bread - better than any my (Jewish) mother has tried in NY or LA!

Room for Improvement: 
One of my moms got the corned beef. It was great as far as flavor but the meat was in such small bits that it kelp falling out of the sandwich. 
How about putting a cucumber or tomato on top of the lox and bagel?

Next time, I want to try the special of the day. It was trout on a bagel yesterday but they ran out just as we were getting to the cash register. Oh and remember to bring cash if you don't want to leave empty-handed. 

PS - Great cross-section of SF represented when we were there from a Chronicle photog who was snapping away to an elderly couple to a bunch of hipsters in skinny jeans.
author: Erin W.

description:
Terrible value.

$12 for a very small sandwich with only average bread, little meat, and no sauce.  It should be $4 for the size.

What?

One of the most disappointing sandwiches I've ever had.
author: D B.

description:
Ordered a #19 from the stand earlier today. The pastrami was very tasty, but some parts of it were a tad more chewy than I would prefer. The #19 was made famous by Langer's Deli in Los Angeles and Wise Guys offer a respectable take on this traditional sandwich. The slaw and double slice of cold swiss were delicious. The homemade rye is much better than Katz's Deli and has good flavor and texture. 

Pickles lacked a some acidity but were fresh.
author: Edwin S.

description: The sandwiches are a little on the small side for the price, but they are big on flavor. The meat from my pastrami sandwich was so ridiculously tender and flavorful it started to make me salivate for more just after the first bite (and now even as I write this review, reminiscing of the times when I could get one so easily at any time)! It was seriously one of the better pastrami sandwiches I've had in my day. Could they be a little more generous on the amount of meat that goes into the sandwich? Sure, but it's still a fantastic sandwich all the same.
author: Erich D.

description:
Time: 3 hrs post-meal 
Status: Food coma level 4. Oy vey.

Mission report: Journeyed to deep Mission neighborhood in quest of delish lunch and friendly jewish company. Split chicken schnitzel sandwich on challah bread and oozing Swiss, sauced, grilled pastrami Reuben. Side of fries and cole slaw. Dessert of chocolate babka. Fantastic sampling and tasting of everything. No disappointments. Will be back. 

Mission Recommendations: Share 2 dishes, come on a weekday, enjoy and eavesdrop on fellow lovely Jewish restaurant compadres. 

Shalom.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I mean if your knives were as sharp as your attitude I MIGHT come back. If you're going to charge $11 for a sandwich learn how to properly cut a brisket, corned beef, or pastrami. It's against the grain. 

I was at your Ferry location today and mentioned to one of your staff that I've been getting tough pastrami and corned beef the last few times because it wasn't cut properly. He had such a shitty condescending attitude I ended up leaving and not ordering anything.

A good deli is more than just the food (which is decent) its the schmooze, the service, the relationships. A million sandwiches in this city - you want them coming back for more. I grew up in the east coast Brooklyn/jersey deli business - my father did and his father before him. Take a tip from a guy who knows- listen to your audience, do the right thing, and remember the customer is always right- always. 

I wish you all the best, but I won't be back. Do yourself a favor- get the right staff and people who love what they do. It's a service business and everyone has a choice...
author: Scotty G.

description: Great deal. Incredibly filling reuben (pastrami) and easily two meals for a normal human being. Little steep but for the location, quantity and quality, $12 is more than reasonable.  They move quick. So even if the line is 10 to 12 ppl, you'll get your sandwich in 3-7 minutes.
author: Mike V.

description: The Turkey Reuben was perfect. Truly delicious and everything that one would want in a reuben. I brought home two coconut macaroons for my family that were not edible. They were so unbelievably salty that the baker must have accidentally put salt into the recipe rather than sugar. I like salty food but these were completely inedible and a waste of the $5 I spent on them [which is rather pricey for two cookies].
author: Sara S.

description: The service was good -- they were very patient with my many questions (What's the diff between corned beef & pastrami (seasoned!)).  The pastrami Reuben was tasty.  The wait wasn't too long.  3 stars as for a place called Wise Sons that many have said is one of the best delis in SF, it just does not quite live up to NY standards of pastrami for me.  But fear not, pastrami lovers.  Amazing pastrami sandwiches are obtainable in SF -- Deli Board rocks!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Is it blasphemous to call this place the Katz's Deli of the West? Wise Sons' pastrami sandwich is the first one I've had outside of Katz's that legitimately impressed me. The meat was tender and had tons of flavor. I just wish the sandwich was bigger (at places like Katz's and Carnegie Deli in NYC, I would have leftovers for several meals after! not the case here, though I guess you're not paying as much...).

One thing I noted, however, was that I was thirsty all afternoon! But it was worth it!
author: J J.

description: Solid pastrami and corned beef sandwiches. Great lunch option and it's much faster than most of the other vendors. Pickles help cut the overall greasy goodness of the sandwiches.
author: Karla R.

description: Had the REUBEN. The sandwich was good, but not enough where I would return. Pastrami slices were thick and hearty. Bread was grilled nicely. Was it worth around $14? Not to me when my local deli could make one for a cheaper price. I wouldn't say no if someone bought me one, just wouldn't go out of my way for one.
author: Jack L.

description:
My wife and I have eaten at and liked very much Wise Sons in the Mission.

Today we looked forward  to going to their booth at Ferry Farmers Market and both ordered the corned beef hash. 

The meal costs $10 so it's not cheap.  Includes two eggs fried, two pieces of WS excellent rye bread and the corned beef hash. So, lots of filling food.

Our beef is with the corned beef hash.  Tasty but mainly potatoes. Not much BEEF!  Take that back -- hardly ANY beef.  Definitely will not order that dish again. And probably not go back to their Ferry booth.

I would have been very happy with one egg, one piece of toast and a real portion of corned BEEF hash.
R
author: Rich S.

description:
They say the way to a man's heart is through his stomach. I feel you on this one.

The way to a Jewish man's heart? Through the Wise Sons' pastrami sandwich.

Between layers of soft yet crusty house-baked rye, piles of moist (but not overly fatty) house-brined and smoked brisket lie in wait for you to lay on the brown mustard. The accompanying potato salad (or cole slaw) forever changed what my perception of these ubiquitous deli sides once was.

The sesame bagel is appropriately slathered in cream cheese and stuffed full of juicy tomato and melt-in-your-mouth lox balanced by just the right number of capers.

Corned beef hash should not be missed. Skip dinner the night before if you have to. Pair it with fresh squeezed juice or bottomless Ritual coffee. Having never tried it before, but having complete faith in these guys, the whitefish salad was light and simply delicious (if you enjoy fish, that is).

I don't have a childhood memory of babka - but this hits the sweet spot between all its flaky, cinnamonly-spicey-chocolatey layers.

I am beyond impressed with what Evan and Leo have pulled off in the past 6 months and I wish them all the best in continuing to crank out the memories. It doesn't hurt that there's something totally charming and handsome going on beneath Leo's nearly pulled back dreads. But I'm guessing he already knows this. 
Keep it up guys. You rock!
(and a big Mazel Tov to you too!)
author: Alissa A.

description:
I'm not Jewish, but at times of my life I've wished I were. I love the culture, the humor and most of all the food. Recently a coworker and I were discussing the dearth of good Jewish delis in San Francisco. Soon after that session of feeling sorry for ourselves, we discovered the My Son's booth at the Ferry Building. 

I got the pastrami sandwich with a side of coleslaw. The pastrami is unusual; it's smoked. It tastes great but was a little tough on the outside. Also, instead of slices the pastrami was in large . . . chips I guess (see photo). So although it wasn't what I expected, I loved it. And the coleslaw was great; slightly tangy, not too sweet, and a slight bite of heat without being too spicy. Everything was delicious.

And although there was a long line, the staff was efficient and friendly. 

Check them out, and mazel tov!
author: Jeff R.

description:
this place is really awesome and underrated compared to some of the other food booths available at the ferry building on tuesdays.

its one of the best reubens i've ever had.
bread is tasty and holds up to all the meat inside.
good sauce and cheese fits nicely with everything.

pickle is a little small but hey, thats okay and not as important.

this place is a gem and I plan on getting the reuben many many times in the future. YUM.
author: Cicely T.

description:
After all the hype, my expectations were high, but Wise Sons Deli was sure to deliver.

I ordered the Open faced Ollie's Bialy & Smoked Salmon. It was absolutely delicious and perfectly filling. The smoked salmon tasted so fresh. The bialy was cooked to perfection, and the chive cream spread brought the whole dish together. The pickled cucumber salad that came on the side was the perfect compliment.

I also got to try a bite of the pastrami on rye. The pastrami was so savory and peppery, the flavor just screamed from it. It went very well with the rye, in fact, i'd say that the combo of the meat and rye is what made the sandwich so good.

I can't wait to go back for more. Until then, I'll just have to dream about that bialy and smoked salmon... yum!
author: Krista S.

description:
Do you love pastrami? Reubens? If you answered yes to either question, then you already love Wise Sons.
I discovered the Tuesday farmer's market in the Ferry Building a few months ago. I had planned to try all the vendors, but have remained very loyal to Wise Sons. It's amazing! The pastrami and corned beef are both high quality and full of exceptional flavor. It's definitely not an inexpensive lunch, but totally worth it for a splurge.
author: Laura B.

description:
This place is really good! And also quite greasy :O, but that's okay. It's so good.

I often frequent the Ferry Building Farmer's Market on Thursdays, but rarely come on Tuesday. So it was my pleasant surprise to stumble upon Wise Sons Delicatessen yesterday. 

I struggled between getting the Reuben, which I could sense would have been spectacular but make me feel oh so bad, and something I thought would be healthier and make me feel less guilty. I tried to be good, and thought the Tuna Melt might possibly be a leaner option, but oh my, foolish me to think that. It was probably just as drenched in delicious butter and crispiness from the stove/grill top as the Reuben would have been, and that is probably why it tasted so delicious. I slapped on a side order of potato salad in my feeble attempt to diversity from pure greasy goodness, and I'm glad I did because it was also delish.

Pretty standard Farmer's Market pricing here:  ~$10 per item, and $2-3 per side. I'm really tempted to give this place 5 stars, but I need to try the Reuben first :-9 (I think that's how you do a licking my lips emoticon). For now, I'll say this is in the 4.4-4.6 star range. Good stuff!
author: Eric S.

description:
Walking home in the rain, I decided to pop into the pop-up :)

Seeing that it was cash only, I pulled out all the money I had in my pocket...7 buckaroos (insert sad violin playing here).

Perusing the menu, I quickly eliminated my first choices - Ollie's Bialy, out.  Pastrami Sandwich, out - hmm, what to get?  I saw that they had a knish special (Corned beef) for $3.50, so I ordered that and the Kale/Mushroom knish to go.  I had no idea what a knish was (pronounced "kh-nish"), but the price was right.  Yay for budgeting skills!

Service was friendly, got to chat for a bit with one of the guys working the counter while I waited for my food, and I observed several tables enjoying their (more than $7) meals.

At home, I peeled back the foil to see two almost-baseball sized dumplings.  I bit into one and was greeted with the warm goodness of kale and mushroom.  I bit into the other and enjoyed mashed potato and corned beef.  Good savory fillings, good crust (just the right balance of soft/crisp and not overly doughy)...yum.

I went back and forth between the two like an infant between two um...well, until I finished each knish. 

I'll be back, armed with cash.  Can't wait to try out my first choices, though I am glad that circumstances led me to the knishes.
author: Moo C.

description: They are efficient and super courteous.  The corned beef was freshly made and delicious!  I loved the rye bread and the babka.  Everything made fresh just like momma would.  The best and most authentic outside of New York!
author: Lisa P.

description:
THEIR CHOCOLATE BABKA IS SO DOPE.

i had it a month and half ago and i STILL can't stop thinking about it. pleeeeease get a permanent restaurant... no more of this pop up crap!!!!!!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Wise sons deli is a pop-up,  only here on saturdays. they are opposite otg Mcchoppin some menu items are only offered till  11 a.m.

sampling: Reuben Pastrimi Sandwich (13.50)
-pastrimi on double baked rye
some pastrimi portions was melt in your mouth, some wasn't
-potato salad,
freshly made red potatoes, firm tats, not mushy, not a lot of flavor.
-with garlic dill pickles
very crunchy.and flavorful

foodnotes:
-orders made to order, items seem pricey.
-menu changes weekly.
-cashier said everything tasted good.
-probable repeat.
-meter maids all over. difficult to find unmetered parking.
author: Victor G.

description:
It's a beautiful sunny day in San Francisco.  Temperature is in the mid-70's.  That and the fact that it is Tuesday, I decided to take 1 mile walk down to the Ferry Building and try Wise Sons.  After standing in line for 15 minutes (it was a long line and this is a very popular place), I ordered a combo corned beef/pastrami sandwich on light rye, a side of coleslaw and an order of their home-made kugel.

The sandwich was great!  It's not "piled high" like I am used to, but it was a decent portion for the price ($11.50).  It came with two pickles.  Real pickles.  Real kosher style deli pickles.  Not those crappy sweet pickles that other so-called jewish delis in the area throw out.  The meat tasted like it was supposed to.  Flavorful and well cured.  My only complaint is that while they offered two kinds of mustard (a sweet mustard and a spicy mustard), they did't have any standard yellow deli mustard available.

The coleslaw was excellent, with a hint of spice, but not overpowering.

The kugel was amazing with green raisins and a crusted top with just the right kind of sweetness.  Almost as good as grandma used to make.  

This place is a must visit for anyone who appreciates good deli food.  I am very picky about my deli food (see my other deli reviews on Yelp).  This one is top notch and I highly recommend it as one of the only two REAL jewish deli's that are doing it right in the bay area.
author: Andrew M.

description:
So it took some time to actually eat here, as you have to chase down their location via twitter. Not the easist way to find where to eat, but in the end totally rewarding as you feel like you earned your sandwich. Any one can eat at subway but you have to know about and find Wise Sons. 

You will be happy you did. I had the pastrami and rye and I have to say the flavor was unlike anything I have tried before. At first you dont realize what you have in front of you in that sandwich. You try it, and its good, but you know how certain spices build hotter and hotter in your mouth? Thats what this sandwich does, but instead of hottness, it does it with awesome. Seriously, after a few bites in I began to have taste overload where all I wanted to do was chew and chew on the same bite because the flavor would not stop. The perfectly (yes perfectly) flavored pastrami mixed with the rye bread in a way I did not know possible. Just brilliant.
author: Tom O.

description: I expected to be wowed, but for $13, the corned beef sandwich was just ok. A bit salty and dry, and kind of anorexic. The highlight was the rye! Should've bought a loaf of that instead.
author: Lisa N.

description:
Man, the pastrami Sando I had at their setup at the Farmers Market was a thing of beauty. It was everything a pastrami on rye should be. 

The bread was fresh and there was plenty of spicy mustard involved.  But, the meat itself...so damn good. The perfect amount of fat, salt, spice and texture.  I was with people and they were waiting on me. So, I had to eat it and get going. But, if I would've had more time, I would have really savored the 'wich.  I even dropped a couple of pieces on the dirty counter and ate them. Haha. I know...so gross. 

I can't wait to get another. These guys show true respect for a Jewish Classic.
author: Dusty B.

description: Overpriced and the pastrami was 3/4 fat. I'm not a health nut and have had hundreds of pastrami sandwiches in authentic NYC delis and this ain't it. 3/4 fat is not pastrami. It's a fat sandwich with a sliver of meat.
author: John B.

description:
Went here with my friend Katya for her first time this past Saturday and there was actually a line (other times, around 10:30am it's been fine), but maybe this place is getting more and more popular.  The guys inside said they are looking for a permanent spot.  

Anyhow I had the Reuben made with corned beef and it was really good. The rye bread was perfectly crunchy and the corned beef was so flaky and tender - could be the best I've had.  The only reason for four stars is that they stop serving breakfast stuff at 11am so I couldn't get the fabulous Semite Sandwich which I was craving this last visit.  It's not made out of semites, but is made with crispy pastrami bacon, fried egg and swiss on their rye bread.  

Hopefully they'll get a nice spot full time that can serve more peeps but go there early and enjoy!
author: Gene X.

description:
I had the corned beef hash here on Saturday and it was amazing. (To the point where I was extremely sad when one of my pieces of corned beef fell on the ground as I was eating.) The egg on top was perfect and the rye bread was also fantastic.  I rarely (never?) find good rye bread in the city so I'm pumped about Wise Sons opening up.

I also had some of the cheese blintzes, which were very good.  My table shared a chocolate babka and loved it... thankfully I didn't get my own because I would have eaten the entire thing.  Overall, everything I had was awesome, but the corned beef hash was the real star.  Yes, I've been daydreaming about it. 

Can't wait till these guys have a permanent place so I don't have to wait a whole week to get some of their food!  For now, they have taken over Jackie's on Saturdays during brunch.  I was there around 11 and they were quite busy, with no open tables.  However, there is extra seating across the street near the Off the Grid food carts.
author: Amy G.

description:
Does this sound familiar to you: 

You're stuck in bed, sick, and the best remedy you can imagine is some of mamma's chicken soup...but momma is cities away.  You grab your computer and type in "san francisco + deli" for a close-by-restaurant search, some jewish matzo soup will certainly do the trick. But, alas, a jewish deli, *any* jewish deli, is nowhere to be found?!

Or how about that re-occurring scenario where an attractive figure is seductively layering thick-cut pastrami onto a slice of homemade rye.  The sweet cream from the cole slow, dripping after every bite.The rich scent of babka floats through the air...but just then, the fog clears, and a faint image of the golden gate bridge begins to appear...and it is only then that you realize... it's all a dream. (no..? that's just me??)

WELL, FRET NO LONGER, GOOD PEOPLE OF SAN FRANCISCO -- boy, do I have the place for you!

Wise Sons Delicatessen is a much needed, long awaited, addition to the San Francisco culinary world.  It is is un-fussied by a large and overwhelming menu (like most delis nowadays) -- and this is by choice, not due to newbie-circumstance.  You won't even come across a large chinese chicken salad ...it's strictly traditional jewish deli talk here.  Simplicity at its best and most delicious.

From in house bread to meats to the best potato salad I've ever had (and I am very picky when it comes to potato salad...normally...I find it "meh") -- 
Their challah has just the right consistency and their babkah -- well, just go try it yourself
I cannot wait to explore the menu at its fullest (and finest), but sadly I will have to wait, as I am not lucky enough to be a resident of sf -- SO...I beg you all...go on my behalf

I will stop now because I hate reading long yelps and I really should just say something honest and easy like -- go here, it's yummy and there's no where else like it...how cool! -- but I will try and be cute once more and just say... make your momma proud!...

Don't be a stupid son or daughter...go to Wise Sons and learn a lil somethin' about deliciousness.
author: Shana B.

description:
Chocolate Babka & Chocolate Egg Cream drink from SF Street Food Fest 2011. Delicious!

Chocolate Babka - massive slice, Challah-like bread laced with thick chocolate. Fantastic for dessert or with a favorite nutty spread (I'm assuming, I couldn't stop eating it as is). This is a very good item.

Chocolate Egg Cream drink - no egg involved, somewhat creamy. Smooth, light chocolately flavor;  I enjoyed it as a drink on its own.
author: Marissa H.

description:
It was more like 2.5 stars but I rounded it up to 3 because the service was solid. 

I got the pastrami sandwich which came with two slices of pickles. Thank god for the pickles, otherwise I would've choked on the grease. The cut of meat was thick and rough, which was fine, owing to the fact that it was a mobile set up and they get rushed. However, the sheer amount of grease, which seeped through the packaging, was unwarranted. Considering that, the price, and the fact that there are so many other deli options out there, I won't be back. BUT the fact that they exist in a city that sorely need more Jewish deli-style food is commendable. 

By the way- they are only at the ferry building on Tuesdays! People seem to make that mistake a lot.
author: Dena R.

description:
Bangin' bagel- and I know bagels. There aren't many good bagels in this city. So thats a huge bonus. 

Cream cheese was herby and yummy. The smoked salmon was good. They didn't have the babka today =( but they had black and white cookies which were great on the black half, and too lemony on the white half. I went early at 9:30 and avoided the line. It was good. Can't wait to try the babka.
author: Emily D.

description:
I came in for brunch last Saturday with friends and was not disappointed.  The babka tasted better than it looks (and it looks really good).  I also ate the corned beef hash which was so yummy and filling that I was powerless against my tastebuds' desire to finish every last crumb.  The rye bread served along with the hash was crispy and fresh - the perfect toast to partner such a rich dish.  

I'm looking forward to next Saturday when I can give the blintzes a try and eat more babka. The babka is just so good.
author: Sarah A.

description:
I really like the quality of the food here. 

PREFACE:
Please know I have the ignorance of a San Francisco West Coast nube, so before the NYC Jewish Mother in you starts telling me about how I don't know what a good babka or reuben is, simmer down. You're right, I know I don't how good it can be in NYC.

HERE'S WHY 3-STARS:
I really liked the quality of my sandwich. Dry corned beef is fine by me. It could have used more sauerkraut, however, I compensated with the coleslaw, and I really liked it, dipping the sandwich in the dressing. It was perfect.

I like their rye and I like their chocolate babka! 

Tip: Don't go hungry. Don't go in a hurry. Don't go with more than one other person (place is too small). Go with the expectation of a long wait time on line and after, but knowing the food is good.

HERE'S WHY NOT 5-STARS:
The wait. Where one can wait, and the actual length of time to wait.

Although it's a deli (suggests you can easily get sandwiches to go), today it took me 30 minutes from the time I  got in line (at the doorway) until I got my corned beef reuben with dressing on the side with cole slaw. The guys who were ahead of me, had their orders 15 minutes before me (I think they got club sandwiches, so maybe those are quicker to make, but hard not to feel like sit-down orders are given priority, vs first-come-first-serve as they say). 30 minutes waiting awkwardly by the register where I felt the blond chic with the high bun was passively aggressively ensuring I knew I was in the way. 

You can't call your order in for pick-up. I tried. They don't do that. Unless it's a catering order.

it is a-okay to me. Try them out!
author: Trinity M.

description: Pastrami Reuben is the reason I must return to Wise Sons each time I visit San Francisco.
author: L J.

description: I was excited to see this place. Unfortunately, it turned out to be extremely disappointing. The matzza ball soup was almost inedible. It tasted like leftover water from boiling a chicken. The noodles were limp and tasteless. The pickled onions saved the small slightly rancid turkey sandwich. $25.00 for soup and sandwich here.... Save your money and go to Lee's down the street
author: philip b.

description:
what i ordered... big macher burger

burger was ok, good amount of meat but don't expect the regular burger taste for you'll get dissapointed as i did. meat was more like a flattened meatball made of finely ground meat then charred  (with a hint of pastrami taste). bun was ok, condiments were minimal and the cheese was real. 

ambiance... ok (it's a stall at farmers market; walk around the building and sit on a bench away from hobo's and gaze at a phenomenal view)
service... so-so (prompt and a robotical thank you)
cost... $+ (expensive)
author: Gors P.

description:
Heard about this place so when I saw them at the Ferry Building today and the line wasn't looking too long, I figured I'd give it a try - especially because I've been having a corned beef craving.

The wait actually was much longer than I thought it would be, but when I turned around after a few minutes, I noticed the line was now incredibly long so I felt committed to staying.

Ordered the corned beef sandwich, which was definitely big enough for me.  The pickles were limp and not very tasty.  The corned beef was a tad fatty and not all that flavorful, also a bit dry.  The rye bread is very good, though, and definitely made the sandwich.

At $9.50 for the sandwich, I thought it was a bit pricey, but it's not bad overall.
author: B. Y.

description: Tried their Brisket Special and it was really good!! Very tender meat, slaw, and melty cheese. The only thing is that they ran out of latkes and those were supposed to be in the sandwich :((((((( I definitely need to come back here and try it with all its proper fixins.
author: Angela D.

description: Try the pastrami chili all beef hot dog on their poppy seed challah roll. Tasty, rich and slightly sweet chili stands up to the dog. Dog itself is snappy, good bite with lots of chew.$8 for a meal that will last you into the next day.
author: Kelly K.

description:
Pastrami on rye with mustard. What more could one want in life.

While working in downtown San Francisco this summer, a weekly pilgrimage of sorts has become the norm. Leaving my office to fly down Market Street on my bike has become a staple of Tuesday at lunch time and I look forward to it immensely.  

The Ferry Building farmers market is always a scene and the Wise and Sons stall is unquestionably a benefit to it. While the line can sometimes be daunting, it always moves quickly and the wait for the food is worth it. While a little pricey, it's San Francisco, and the sandwiches created here are classic and delicious.

In other words, if you want a pastrami sandwich, look no further.
author: Daniel S.

description:
My wife and I enjoyed lunch here today and the food was really top drawer. Best rye bread I've had in almost six years of living in the West. A bialy with a crisp crust is definitely non-traditional but it was excellent. 
Probably would have given them five stars but I'm having trouble with a Jewish deli serving dairy with meat. But if you open a Portland location, I'll be there!
author: Alan G.

description:
Dear San Franciscans,
Sadly, it is clear that you have never experienced what babka really tastes like, ergo, Wise Sons seems killer. Some day, you may know the true joy of eating a moist, sweet bread which has layers of sweet chocolate thickly swirled throughout. The babka at Wise Sons had a dry taste to the bread, and WTF, the chocolate was bittersweet! So wrong...

It may take a trip to  NY, to some of the remaining Jewish bakeries, to truly know what the babka should be.
author: Carla B.

description:
Perhaps I'll start out by saying that I hope to re-review Wise Sons down the road when they've established themselves in a more permanent setting. However, in their current location, I just can't say they're ready for prime time just yet.  While the food was good (in some cases, very good--more on that in a sec), the experience I had there was just awful.

I was very excited to see another Jewish deli opening up in town, even if it was a pop-up restaurant. My people can't get enough of our roots in SF for reasons that have always escaped me. So, I was eager to give this new place a try. 

According to their pre-published menu, they start serving sammies around 11 a.m., so my friends and I arrived around 11:40 at their pop-up location on Valencia... a smallish cafe that is not set up for food prep. (They use hot plates to heat everything up.) As you can see by the other reviews on here, the word is out: the line was out the door and nearly a dozen people were standing inside waiting for their food.
When we got to the front of the line, the very nice guy taking orders informed us that they were already out of pastrami (!!), did not have any more of the chocolate babka (other than a few samples, which were delish) and were nearly out of corned beef. Um, that's like a third of their menu. I wanted corned beef anyway, so I felt fortunate. I noshed on a truly wonderful pickle (also set out as a sample of sorts) in hopes it would tide me over.

Then the waiting started... and went on... and on... and on. It took at least a half hour for my sandwich to arrive. In that time, a part of eight people arrived and got in line. By the way they were acting and interacting with the staff, it became very apparent that they were friends of the staff or possibly investors. About half of them got out of line and claimed eight of the maybe 20 seats in the café, despite the fact that there were nearly ten people who had already ordered waiting for a place to sit. When I mentioned it to one of the women that my friends and I were ahead of her and waiting for a table she was, shall we say, less than sympathetic. But her snotty rudeness isn't the restaurant's fault, is it? Just wait.

Remember the chocolate babka they were out of? While I stood waiting for my food, a full plate of it magically appeared from the back and was offered to the Friends of Wise party. How thoughtful!
Also, when my order came up, in a tone that was neither hostile nor bitchy, I said to the man behind the counter I thought it "was not cool" that (despite their posted signs stating, "Please be respectful of others waiting to eat") they allowed parties to sit down when they hadn't even ordered yet, since it meant other customers (like my friends and me) basically had to go outside, stand on the sidewalk, and eat there. He stared at me, almost irritated, and said, "Well there's nothing I can do about it," and walked away.  Seriously? Don't you WORK here? In disbelief I walked away and ate my sandwich outside.

(And I would point out, by the way, that I was done eating before the Friends of Wise had even finished ordering, let alone received their food. Also, they had long since run out of corned beef as well by then but, aside from putting up a sign inside the restaurant, never went outside to tell those standing in line.)

Again, I have to point out in the spirit of fairness that Wise's food was good. My corned beef, while seasoned really well, was incredibly fatty. For $12, there really wasn't that much meat on the bread (at least when compared to other Jewish delis I've visited in SF, Chicago, LA and NYC). The bread was excellent and had a perfectly chewy-crunchy crust. The potato salad wasn't extraordinary, but was pretty decent.

If it wasn't for the experience I had here, I would give this place four stars in a heartbeat. If the Wises want to really open a class-act deli, they need to cater to all of their customers, not just those who quite clearly appear to be their friends. (Not to mention finding even a pop-up space more appropriate to their operation.) Bad food can certainly drive customers away, but a bad experience can also be equally repellant. 

I hope to visit again soon and give a better rating, but as they stand now, I won't be back.
author: Aaron L.

description: Not worth the wait. I am from ny and although this place makes an attempt w the steamed, hand cut corned beef and pastrami, this was one of the chewiest, fattiest corned beef sandwiches I have ever had! Half the meat on my sandwich was so chewy it was inedible.  Pickles are good, but they don't tell you the sandwich comes w them so I ordered a pickle plate and all it was is one additional pickle for 2.50. Probably won't wait in that line again.
author: rachel k.

description:
finally a product I can get behind.  wise sons is the real deal.  I've been twice now and had the corn beef the pastrami and the brisket.  the pastrami is outstanding. they cut it thick but it is still tender.  the smoking process really give it a deep flavor.  they make their own rye bread and pickles 2 things I don't take lightly . luckily neither do they . also home made were their "holla" rolls.  we spoke with 1 of the owners who was very nice and spent time talking to us even though he was busy.  why is sons is legit I can't wait for them to get a restaurant space.


we went back again this week (third week in a row) I have decided that wise sons makes the best pastrami I'VE EVER TASTED!!! awesome.  AND SCHMALTZ!!! holy schnikes a revalation.  My great grandmother Rae was smiling down watching me eat schmaltz.

they are still working out some kinks... matzo ball soup was good but not hot enough (balls were cold in center) they heated for me the second time around properly.  potato salad is decent but potatoes were underdone for my taste.  but who cares... it's flippin slammin omfg it was so good today.  Wise Sons needs a space quick.
author: ari b.

description:
We have been trying to go for a while but since they only pop up occasionally, it has never worked out until last Saturday. We got there at 11:30 and there was already a huge line out the door for people waiting to order. The menu was limited but really good. Between 5 of my friends, we ordered and tried the majority of the dishes. My favorite was the pastrami Reuben. The meat was juicy and really well cooked. Also, they make their own rye bread, which was very fresh and worked nicely with the sandwich. When we were waiting in line the portions that other people had looked on the smaller side. However, in practice, the portions were just the right size. I was definitely very full when I was done. 

The venue itself was pretty functional. It has several long tables that different groups of people can share. Despite the large amount of people waiting to order, we found seats almost immediately. I would definitely come back to this place again when my schedule works out with their work day.
author: Kate G.

description:
I was in San Francisco a couple of weeks and was lucky enough to have come across this fine establishment. 

It was my third time in the city by the bay and was in the Mission District to look at the murals, but first, my friends and I needed breakfast. We went to yelp and Wise Sons popped up. Since were weren't finding much else around the neighborhood, we decided to eat here. And we're glad we did! 

It was pretty busy when we got there and were a little concerned about seating but was able to snag a table outside. The staff is great. The cashier had a smile on her face, despite the countless amount of people making orders. Another staff member, upon seeing that we had snagged a seat outside, changed our order from "to-go" to "here." I loved that he was concerned about the waste we would be creating by using the to-go cartons as opposed to plates.   

I don't really remember what my friends ordered--even though I did share with one of them--but I got the Challah French Toast. It was DELICIOUS! I have had challah bread before, and really liked it, but as French Toast.... Amazing! It was a life changing moment. The generic, run-of-the-mill French Toast just won't cut it anymore. 

The next time I'm in San Francisco I will definitely make a point to come here again. In the meantime, I'll have to get some challah bread and try re-create this delicious masterpiece.
author: Chante G.

description:
New location, new level of delicious.

Evan and Leo are my heroes.

EVERYTHING was delicious, and I'll be back as many times as I can.
author: adam t.

description:
this place is great. I tried the open faced ollie's bialy and smoked salmon which was perfect. The sweet and sour pickled cucumbers on the side were so good, don't miss it.

I also tried the pastrami scramble - it was good, the onions were in big pieces - so tasty. they serve it with a little cream cheese, toast (full of butter) and potatoes kugel - which also was very tasty.

The tastes here are just the way my grandmother used to make things, a real homey kind of taste, simple ingredients and tastes, but very good.

Please notice it's a cash only! so come prepared.
author: Too M.

description:
Practice makes perfect

I'm going to try to be objective, which is going to be really difficult considering my "even when it's bad it's good" theory of pastrami.  Like everyone else, I've been longing for some NY deli here in multicultural land.  It never crossed my mind how hard that would be.  Perfecting a recipe for one dish takes tremendous effort, let alone a menuful.

I'm here for the pastrami.  On rye. With cole slaw. And a pickle. 

The bread is excellent.  Crispy crust, not too much caraway and a soft interior that stands up to the meat. It is a very good platform for what is to come.

The pastrami is a work in progress.  Cut "brisket thick" with a good peppery crust, a bit of smoky something and served perfectly warm.  A few bites were tough, I chalk that up to the thicker cut.  Thing is, the stuff holds up on its own, sans bread, it leaves a slightly salty, peppery heat after each bite.

Which leads to the cole slaw, a nice blend of white and purple cabbage with a good bit of carrot for sweetness to balance out the pepper of the pastrami.  As anyone who has made  cole slaw in large batches will tell you, the dressing sinks to the bottom.  You have to continuously stir it before service.  That said, the dressing seems light, with a good balance of sweet and vinegar.  Remember to stir in now and then.

Pickles.  My Mom made pickles in a big crock in the back yard when I was a kid.  Now Mom is a hard-core garlic pickle master, so my palate was really unprepared for the subtle masterpiece the Wise guys have produced.  See, when you're doing the pastrami thing, you really don't need a salty, vinegary tsunami overwhelming the saltiness of the pastrami or the vinegar of the cole slaw. This is a  cucumbery pickle that adds the crunch without the pucker. A bit more dill wouldn't do it any harm, either.

And get a slice of babka.  You won't be sorry.

Sandwich & sides: $12 Babka $3

When they start making egg creams, I'm moving in.
author: Der G.

description:
I think I'm mirroring a couple other reviews here... but really all I can say is "AT LAST!"

Leo and Evan have started wheels turning on an unstoppable Deli EXTRAVAGANZA that SF has been yearning for for a long time.

If you can think it, they've been tinkering in their lab of a kitchen on bigger, tastier and ways to make it.  I've tasted Pastrami that melts into butter (like dreams i've had), Corned beef sent straight from heaven, and baked goods that should have Grand Bakery shaking in their boots.

This place and these guys are NOT to miss!  The breakfast last week was awesome with sweet sweet blintzes (covered in creme fraiiche haha love the SP episode) with a fruit compote, corned beef hash with a fried egg, and home baked Biali's with Chive creamcheese and lox.

I've heard a rumor of CHOCOLATE BABKA FRENCH TOAST (thats just slap yo mamma good) on the menu for this saturday, but i don't think anything is confirmed.

Check it out! I know I'll be there...
author: Joseph F.

description: I've been going here since they opened. each time, the meal gets worse. Last time is my last visit. The meat was hard and dry. Cheap quality meat, poorly prepared. They've fallen a LONG way from their origins.
author: Eater S.

description:
I'd been hearing about these guys and really wanting to give them a try. Why only 4 stars - because I took too long getting there today and they were OUT of so much stuff. But I did have a great corned beef sandwich (I would have liked a bit more fat), potato salad (my first choice was coleslaw but it was out) and 2 nice spears of pickle. I could see how some folks might think the sandwich is small. I think it's perfect. Remember this is organic meat with artisan "corning", organic homemade pickles and organic potato salad ingredients - that stuff is expensive and takes time. A slice of delicious chocolate babka was the perfect ending. Would have liked a root beer but it was, yes indeed, OUT. HA!

Next time - and there most definitely will be a next time, I will get my ass there earlier.
author: holly B.

description:
Pastrami's where it's at. enough said.
Anyone who can make their own bialys should be respected. 
Faith is with the wise sons
author: Jeff D.

description: It took FOREVER to get my hot dog (and why would you put sauerkraut on a hot dog?!), but it was pretty good.  My mom, however, makes significantly better matzoh ball soup.  Not really impressed.  Michelle did say her corned beef sandwich was delightful.
author: Nora S.

description: Like many others have mentioned, good sandwich but not enough for the price.  $14 for a reuben yikes!
author: Phil L.

description: Good food, great sandwiches, but not as good as the stuff in New York. But when I miss the pastrami or corned beef it's still a good fix.
author: Richard W.

description:
If you're a fan of Jewish deli food you must check this place out! My husband and I both ordered the corned beef sammies on rye with a side of chopped liver, one with potato salad and the other with slaw and pickles. We also had a side of pickled treats and some rugelach to go. I've had quite a bit of corned beef in my day and Wise Sons' was amazing! The meat was so juicy, piled on high, with a ton of fat. Portions were just perfect as well. 

The best seats in the house if you can nab them are at the bar so you can watch all the carving action! I walked in hungry but was salivating by the time our sandwiches came. All the employees were also very nice and seemed passionate about what they were doing. 

Today was their last day popping up at Heart before they move onto another spot in the mission over at Beast and the Hare. Also note that it's cash only. I can't wait to go back and try that pastrami reuben!
author: Foodie K.

description: The pastrami sandwich is solid. The prices are a bit steep, but given the location, it is understandable.
author: Brian K.

description:
Overall a great place. During their event on Saturday, I had the bialy and babka. I am diary-free, but they had tofu cream cheese (btw this stuff is really hard to get outside of NY). The bialy was perfect and great lox on it as well. It was served with pickles, which were really sweet like I like them. 

The babka was really good as well - perhaps the best I have had, except maybe from Issac's in Brooklyn (but those guys have been doing it since they left the shetl). 

Great service, fair prices, nice crowd... what else can you ask for?
author: M L.

description: ....went by again yesterday...few people in line...prices outrageous for this level quality....great for the lazy or unknowlegable...
author: jim b.

description:
Sandwich 10.50.  Cole slaw and potato salad 5 bucks.  Small portions.

If they increased meat x 2 and threw in the cole slaw and potato salad i might go back.  Of course that will never happen and i will never go back.

15.50  for a sandwich and a couple sides is just too much.
author: michael k.

description:
Oh wow, chocolate babka french toast!!! That babka is to die for, I wish I could eat it for every meal for the rest of my life! Since there are no other places to get quality Jew food in the city, this place deserves a heary four starts.

These little upstarts have a long way to go, but I can't wait until they have their own location and are not limited by their host's timelines.

Tip: go their early and you will miss the line.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
I would like to thank Matt Cohen of OTG for supporting Wise Sons in their pop-up.   Neither Russ and Daughters nor Second Ave Deli are close enough to take care of those reuben cravings that hit a couple of times a month.  SF the city with every type of food on planet earth does not have a decent Jewish Deli (or Egyptian Food, but that is a separate rant).  I cannot wait until these lovely boys get a permanent location.

The cafe they pop-up in is small and lacking of space.  Lines are long, people hover over you while you try to eat and overall it lacks appeal.  Is it worth feeding meters twice, standing in line for 20+ minutes and then waiting for your food?  Holy crap, yes.

So visit one (sometime in the beginning of February)  my hubby and I (and friends) shared a corned beef sandwich and a reuben sandwich....hands down best reuben ever. The corned beef was moist and flavorful but a little fatty for my taste.  Portions are California size, not NYC size...then again the sandwiches are not 17.50 either.

Second visit  there was a white fish sandwich on the menu.  OMG, I would have ordered a second if I knew it was going to be so good.  We also ordered another reuben (just as good as the first time) and a pickle plate.  The pickle plate was so good: not just pickles but radishes, beets and onions.  Yum yum yum.

The food is fabulous, the staff works as fast as they can..I just hope they get a real location soon, since that is the most frustrating part of the yummy Wise Sons Deli Experience.
author: Monika S.

description:
When my husband sent me a story about this place this week I was besides myself with excitement --good deli in the Mission, really(!?!!!) So of course we had to come check it out this morning and boy it does not disappoint.  We both had the corn beef and hash --ohmygoodness yummy! Some of the best corn beef I have ever had and super fresh and tasty potatoes with the yummy horseradish sauce--plus I don't usually like rye bread and I ate two whole delicious slices --it was baked so perfectly between the crispy crust and the chewy center and the flavor was tasty and not overwhelming) 

Not only was the food absolutely delicious but the customer service was outstanding (everybody was friendly, welcoming, helpful and appreciative!)  and as a bonus--they use all compostable items including forks and cups:) Wise Sons made me extremely happy in every way!! Not to mention that it is surprisingly near impossible to find good deli food in SF besides Millers which is quite a distance a way for those of us who live in the Mission.  And if the rest of their food is as good as what we had this morning then I definitely think they will trump their competition (especially if they can whip up some delicious matzoh ball soup and put pickles on the table!) 

 I cannot wait until they have an actual restaurant where we can eat there any time rather than having to wait for a Saturday. It is just that good.
author: Alisa D.

description: I love everything about Wise Sons. The food is delicious and always consistent. The service is great and the ambiance is fun and warm. Highly, highly recommended!!
author: Leah W.

description:
Amazing pop -up deli that makes up for a limited menu with spectacular quality.  I had the house trout on an open face homemade bagel...they don't really have a selection of bagels, and the bagel itself was not amazing, but it was really just a vessel for the delectable trout that more than made up for it.  The sweet and sour cucumbers on the side were a great touch.  

We were at Wise Sons at Heart, and shared a long table with some strangers who were kind enough to share their chopped liver, which was was sweetly pureed perfection.  Last time in life I hope I am taking liver donations.

We also had an order of the schtetl toast, coated with radishes and dill it was really a unique item, and one I am already craving again the next morning.  They didn't have hot coffee, but their iced coffee was great, and perfect for a rare hot San Francisco summer day.

All in all Wise Sons clearly picks its menu battles, but it does so wisely and your taste buds will not be disappointed.
author: Aaron S.

description:
I had brunch at the pop-up inside Jackie's Cafe and had a bit of everything. The cheese blintzes were perfect -  a nice creamy texture, not too sweet and topped with a dried fruit compote. The corned beef hash was fantastic! The corned beef was high quality flavorful meat served with a eggs and fantastic house made rye. The bialys were just the right size, chewy and a perfect amount of onion and were served with a side of sweet pickles. 
The service was speedy and friendly, I got my food in about 5 minutes. They were cash only but nothing was more $9, so you really can't beat the price. I will definitely be heading back for more and am looking forward to trying out some lunch items in the future.
author: Amiee K.

description: Can I say drop dead delicious?!    Well there I said it!  I can't wait till they find a a permanent home so I can taste what else they have to offer than their breakfast menu of already delicious corn beef hash and melt in your mouth french toast.  But in the mean time I can come back every Saturday and look forward to what else they have to offer each week.  The portions are just the perfect size.  I know this is a long time in the making and it's clear in their dishes.  Try it out for yourself.  I highly recommend it!
author: Jessica C.

description: Awesome! Some of the best pastrami I've ever had.  Puts up a fight to the Katz Deli pastrami in NYC.  A little overpriced, but you're in SF at the Ferry Building--should be expected.  Would be 5 stars if they were quicker--a very simple pastrami can take upwards of 20 minutes sometimes, even more at peak hours.
author: Ryan H.

description:
What a great random find. The corned beef hash was awesome. The service was quick and helpful with just enough "hipster cool" to make you wanna come back. I would say hit this while you can still get a seat without waiting for hours. 

Great job guys!
author: Jeremy K.

description:
4-Star sandwich with a 3-star price. 

I got the turkey reuben and it was very tasty!  I thought the turkey had a very nice smokey flavor.  The rye was solid (and toasted) and the amount of thousand island was perfect!  I did however find that the sandwich could use a bit more sauerkraut, but maybe that's just the German in me.

The sandwich came with two (small-sized) pickle halves that were excellent!  I just wish they were larger!

Overall, a really solid lunch spot; however, at $12 for a sandwich and half pickle, it will be difficult to make this a regular/frequent lunch spot.
author: Alexander H.

description:
Had the pleasure of sampling some of this new Deli's eats at small preview session a few weeks ago.

The corned beef was stellar, and i don't even love corned beef.
The challah was salty and soft and delicious.

Even the pickles were their own special concoction that was a little but spicy and very flavorful. Can't wait to go back and try even more and more and more and.....more please?
author: ALEXIS B.

description: I wouldn't change anything about this place.  Worth every penny for good ingredients and careful preparation.
author: Otto D.

description:
Whoa...who knew that pop-ups were so expensive?
I get that we live in SF, the world of $4.25 gas and $5 organic cage free eggs, but geez, Wise Sons is overpriced.

Went there last Saturday and paid $11 for a medium sized bialy with salmon and $12 for a pathetically small corned beef sandwich.  The food was delicious and I agree it's important to balance both quantity and quality, but come on!  This is a pop-up, not Gary Danko.
author: Betty Y.

description: Visited the Contemporary Jewish Museum branch and tried only one thing: the chopped liver sandwich. And it was DIVINE. The best chopped liver in a long time, rye sourdough, heaven!
author: Flora T.

description: Everything Wise Sons does has been a 5 down to their home-made rye bread.  Today's stroll past Farmer's Market waylaid by the WS popup ... and a reuben. OK I can die now.  The balance of flavors and textures, just off the chart.  Thanks guys!
author: Bob K.

description:
Agreed, food was delish, but a bit $$$?
Try the Semite sandwich for brkfst, soooooo good.
Will be back for Babka!!!
author: alina v.

description: That pastrami sandwich makes me want to be Jewish. Holla! I mean, Challah!
author: Jen Y.

description: Tried their version of the langers deli #19.  Pastrami, swiss, russian dressing, coleslaw on rye.  The standout for me here was the rye bread they use.  The meat wasn't up to langers level in volume or taste, coleslaw was a little chunky and either the russian dressing wasn't very flavorful or they didn't put enough on.  Still one of the better pastrami based sandwiches I've had in the bay area.
author: Mike I.

description: All I've had is the pastrami on rye, but holy cow is it amazingly good!  Pretty easily the best pastrami I've ever had.  Incredibly smoky, juicy and tender.  Note that all you get is several thick slices of pastrami on rye.  That's it. They'll give you a small container of mustard, but you really don't need it.  This sandwich manages to be both no-frills and decadent at the same time.  The rest of the menu appears to be chock full of tasty options, and I look forward to trying them all.
author: Andrew E.

description: Good meat but small portion and pricey...
author: JK C.

description:
This review is for the catering service.  

I was looking for real Jewish deli catering for my event, and did a bunch of Google & Yelp searches.  I stumbled upon Wise Sons during my research and I'm sure glad I did.  Tinkerbell was helpful in working w/ me on the menu.
