Even though I ordered for 40, I was still a bit nervous about running out of food as some of the reviews on Yelp were that the portions were a bit on the smaller side.  My concerns were unfounded.  There was plenty of food and still a lot leftover from my big party.  Most importantly, my guests said they loved all the food.  Many asked where the food was from and a big testament was that there was a lot of continued noshing (people getting 2nd & 3rds) through the very end.  I ordered the smoked fish platter - the salmon was the first to go but I thought the trout salad was one of my favorites.  The pastrami & corn beef platter was consumed immediately with only the smoked turkey & egg salad sandwiches leftover.  The chopped liver was delicious.  The babka was out of this world - rich chocolate, moist & decadent.  The bagels from Beauty's were crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside.  My guests commented frequently that the bagels were outstanding.  There were a lot of accoutrement that came with all the dishes.  I would cater from Wise Sons again in a heartbeat!  Thanks Wise Sons!!!
author: Ha N.

description: Went today for a Gilt City deal of brunch for two. Everything we ate was incredible! We had bagels with lox smear, onions, capers, home made pickles and a bunch of other goodies. We also bought a loaf of the fresh rye and a jar of pickled beets. I can't wait to go back to try the pastrami sandwiches. All that keeps me from giving 5 stars is the woman working the front counter was rather rude. When we asked for some knifes she said that they didn't have any even though they were very clearly right behind her and then she watched me wait for about fifteen minutes for the jar of beets.All of the other staff were incredibly welcoming and helpful. I will definitely will come back, but hopefully on a day they have a nicer staff person at the register.
author: Alexandra F.

description:
holy moses these guys are the best. 

it's way better then going to shuel for your religious experience. their  pastrami on rye with chopped liver is my reason for living.
author: tinkerbell e.

description: Do you have half of afternoon to kill standing in line for incredibly greasy grub? Wise Sons Delicatessen at the Ferry Building.Two! lines to get your grease soaked container? You first stand in a ridiculous line to place an order - there are only 4 items on the menu, but when you write each order down and calculate total in your head, yeah it does take 20 minutes to place an order. Then you move in into the next line, the pickup line. Fast forward Another! 20 minutes later, your name gets called and if you haven't left by now, you get your food. Think with that wait time it must be worth it? Hardly, all I taste is grease, lots of it. The food is very fatty, seriously not cool to have that much of just beef lard in each slice of pastrami. I don't care about thrown away money for shoddy food, give me back 40 minutes of my life!!!
author: Try E.

description: At Ferry's Building farmers market, Tuesdays only.  We had a pastrami sandwich ($9), burger of the day ($11), and babka ($3.5) chocolate cake.  The burger was our favorite.  SOO juicy and the buns were toasted to perfection.  They have different burger every week, so I will love to go back and try another one next time.  Pastrami sandwich was popular but i thought it was okay.... not warm or moist enough for my liking.  Rye bread was good. Babka was really rich, i couldn't finish it.
author: Jessica N.

description:
Best Reuben sandwich ever. 

Went Sunday at 1pm, was a line...not huge maybe 30 min wait, which is a-ok because you get to watch the cooks creative and fry up some amazing food while your drooling over the wise sons menu. 

When asking for suggestions the staff were very non-committal, which in the end was justified because we loved our food and were steered correctly by the menu instead of a buzz factor

My hubby ordered double meat on his reuben. Definitely not required but made for an extra OOMPH on the yum-factor. 

I had the trout salad sandwich, an unusual choice, but i really liked it. much lighter than the reuben and just as flavorful. 

the hardest part is waiting for your order....but totally worth it
author: Christine f.

description:
Finally we made it AND got to eat there (the first time they'd run out of meat after we'd waited in line for 30 min, in the Rain). YES the pastrami was as good as I'd imagined, (although I tend to like it a little bit leaner). The Ruben I had a bite of also did not disappoint. We are talking about quality house cured meats on delicious rye bread. So simple and so effen good!
The potato salad was a bit chunky and toothsome, lightly dressed in a fresh herby dressing. The cole slaw blew my mind- seriously, I'm going to try and duplicate it at home. Straightforward, a little tangy but not too creamy. Awesome! The pickles were pretty fabulous too. 
I didn't care for the black and white cookie, it seemed under-baked and over-sweet. Next time I want to try the potato kugels and the pickle plate (which had carrots, kraut, pickles, beets). Both looked incredible.
Very freakin' expensive but so worth it. A special occasion kind of lunch. Such a treat! Been waiting for West Coast style Jewish deli food and this delivered!
author: Rachel D.

description: Bialy egg sandwich + pastrami = the best.  Smoked trout salad, challah french toast, matzo ball soup and super friendly people all make a trip to Wise Sons totally worth the wait in line.  If you're not up for it, a mid-morning weekday breakfast is the key to avoiding the crowds.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This is one of those places where I truly, truly wish I could give half stars. I'd give it a solid 3.5, mostly because I'm one of those people who turns my noses up at places getting any less than that when I'm looking for food on yelp and I *liked* Wise Son's. I want it to do well, I just have some constructive crits.

For any of us paying attention to the Jewish Deli crisis in this city and others, there's a lot of talk about what exactly a Jewish deli is. Much of this is tied up in nostalgia and myths of epic sandwiches the size of your head, never ending metal bowls of pickles, and chicken liver that punches you in the face with it's liver-y-ness (screw you, pate). But at places that serve things like that the quality of the meat, bread, pickles, etc, tends to be so-so. Quantity over quality. Which my cranky old Jewish antielitist-snob dad loves but the foody in me tends to shy away from. The modern Jewish deli seems to be going away from that focus and looking at 1) buying sustainable and local meats/bagels/bread/etc and 2) doing their own foodyness- smoking their own salmon, corning their own beef, baking their own stuff (remember, a lot of this is outsourced out our favorite old-fashioned delis).  All of this drives up prices, unfortunately. 

Wise son's is clearly a modern Jewish deli and is trying to do both of those things, and they do it very successfully! The corned beef was superb, the smoked trout and salmon amazing, the babka to die for (and those of us who've made it know that it should be slightly dry and the chocolate kind of "pasty"- so shut up, haters). But I have two words for Wise son's : Happy Medium. 

The portions were really small, even though it was really delicious. I had the smoked trout on a bagel, for instance (they were out of lox and they offered to sub the trout for it). The bagel was everything a bagel should be- chewy, dense, perfectly full of sesame, kind of sweet in that mouthy chewing way (hooray malt syrup). And the smoked trout was so friggin' good. But it was small. Way smaller than the 11$ I was charged warranted. Guys. I know that you won't loose that much money by making your portions bigger, so please do! And charging for a *tiny* plate of pickles. No. Offer a "never-ending" bowl for something cheap (3 bucks, max) and it'll go over huge, I promise.

Now maybe these things will be fixed when they have a proper location and room to spread out. Maybe they'll start having big ol' barrels of pickles at the counter and way more spreads and meats to spread around (they have to make everything beforehand in what I can only imagine is a tiny space or even a home kitchen). I certainly hope so. I'll be going back when they have a permanent location and I hope they find the Happy Medium.
author: Carly S.

description: Best Jewish Deli food this side of the Mississippi! My Jewish baby, husband, and in-laws love it! Though my father-in-law calls it wise brothers ;)
author: Cee B.

description: I wanted to try most things on the menu before reviewing. The food is quality, the service friendly, and the menu is constantly being reinvented and improved. I highly recommend recommend swing by next Saturday. Can't wait for this place to get a permanent location!
author: Eli D.

description: Pastrami reuben? I'm there! Quality sandwiches like those you would find at The Sentinel, and they all come with two pickles which is always a bonus. Watch out for long lines if you come after 12pm.
author: Claire C.

description: Nothing less than 5 Stars for the best  bialy, lox and babka in town. Can't wait til they start bringing the sandwiches in as well!
author: Matt C.

description: First off it's hard to judge a pastrami sandwich if you're the type of person that will eat it any time of the day. The cut was pretty thick as well as heavily peppered which I really though distinguished it from other delis that cut it thinner thereby losing a lot of the texture to the sandwich. The one thing I will say is that if you were judging this place based on service it would definitely be two stars. The people here are friendly but the ordering system was very disorganized leading to an inordinate wait time for our takeout sandwiches.
author: Procter F.

description: Best pastrami sandwich in SF.  There isn't much competition sadly, but this is the closest thing to a Langer's experience I've yet found.
author: John D.

description: I really enjoyed their pickle plate, and the food was tasty. The service was extremely friendly, and I hope to see them again to taste some other things on their menu.
author: Benjamin T.

description: Great service, but the sandwiches were average. Got a corn beef and a pastrami, and they were both fine, just unmemorable.
author: Greg S.

description: Apparently this Saturday-only pop-up Jewish style deli is a part of the "Off the Grid" mobile food program. The menu looks like it changes from week to week, based on the prior reviews. I tasted several interesting things this week, including an open faced bialy with lox and brisket sandwich. The open faced bialy was solid--good proportion of lox, cream cheese, a few capers, and very thinly sliced red onion. It came with some amazing quick-pickle cucumbers. The brisket sandwich was tasty, but we were looking for more of a sliced brisket sandwich, while this sandwich contained more of a shredded beef--almost pot roast-like brisket. However, it came with some pickled vegetables and cabbage, and we were not disappointed. The staff was super friendly and very helpful.
author: Timothy V.

description: I'm not normally a pastrami fan but I had their pastrami last night at the Pacific Brew Labs event and was smitten. Juicy, tender and not overly salted perfectly fatty meat...oh, and this pickles? Awesome.
author: L N.

description: I can't say enough great things about Wise Sons Deli. A group of us went for the first time this past weekend. The operation is well run. They take your order and you pay before you get seated. They give you a number to post on your table so they know where to bring your order. Now, The food, INCREDIBLE!! For all of us who keep complaining that there is no decent deli outside of NYC and Montreal, you will not be disappointed. The pastrami is beyond good. The pickles taste like they came from the 2nd Ave. Deli. One of the owners came by to check on us and he couldn't be nicer. What a mensch! The whole experience was worth it and I am planning my next trip already.
author: Stuart K.

description:
We had brunch here this morning, at the pop-up inside Jackie's cafe, and they did not disappoint.

Corned beef hash: amazingly moist, tender, and flavorful. This is the real thing and you can taste it. It was prepared perfectly, without too much oil or salt -- just right. Came with scrambled eggs (not too dry or runny!) and crispy rye toast from a homemade loaf with just enough of a touch of caraway flavor.

Blintzes: They really are just like my mom used to make - light, perfectly browned, and with a filling that doesn't overpower the crepe.

Bialy: crunchy outside, soft inside, with a delicious filling and lox -- yum.

If they can keep this level of quality up and find suitable permanent space, this place will be a big hit.
author: Russell B.

description:
I came at noon, so though I was disappointed to have missed the corned beef hash (not to mention the cheese blitzes which were also sold out), I was NOT disappointed by the chocolate babka and biali+cream cheese which were all that left.  They were all house-made and heavenly delicious.  Picking up a loaf of that babka would be great for a weekend brunch at home.  

Great new place, can't wait to wake up early next week for the real thing!
author: Debbie M.

description:
I finally got to eat the chocolate babka here and it is very good!   The babka is a rich and dark chocolate encased in a very tasty and well baked dough.  They do make a chocolate babka french toast, but did not have that today.  I am looking forward to trying that.  I have had the white fish salad on rye toast the past 2 weekends and it is very tasty and enjoyabe.  The rye bread is some of the best I have tasted in San Francisco.   The dill pickles were much better today than last weekend.  Wise Sons is trying to get a permanent location in San Francisco and I cannot wait unitl that happens.  In the meantime, I highly recommend this place.    

B
author: Bernie B.

description: Fantastic Bialy. Can't wait till they open in a permanent location.  Wonderful service
author: Gary C.

description: If you're into corned beef and pastrami, this is a great scene, very tasty food! The pastrami bacon was especially good.  The service isn't especially efficient and the space is cramped, but that's part of the charm.
author: Syd S.

description:
I've never been a corn beef hash fan--usually the corn beef is average and the potatoes overcooked.

This was not the case with the Wise Sons' rendition. The meat was rich with flavor, the chunks of corn beef plentiful, and the potatoes crispy and full of flavor. The egg served on top was just such a great compliment. I was sharing the CB Hash along with other items with a few friends, and it was so good I went back for another order just for myself.

The guys opening this place up seem down to earth and eager to please. I'm excited for the future of Wise Sons as a mainstay deli in SF!
author: Scott S.

description:
Why didn't I order everything on the menu??? Amazing and superbly cooked deli food. My friend and I split the corned beef hash, babka and blintzes. 

The corned beef hash was the best I have ever had. The corned beef was so perfectly cooked that it just melted in your mouth. The potatoes and egg only added to the already mouth-watering flavor. 

The babka was the perfect treat. It had an amazing consistency that left me wanting more. 

Last, the blintzes were off the chart. They did not rely on sugar to mask any flavors. The crepe was light and fluffy with a yummy cheese filling and topped with a delicious fruit compote. 

Cannot wait to go back and eat more next time I am in SF!
author: Lauren R.

description:
i didn't want to like them b/c they're hip, the signage is cool & there's a long wait.
in fact i was crabby when the husband insisted we wait in line. - about 15 mins.
BUt, the cole slaw is fresh& yummy (not in a soup of mayo/cabbage juice), the smoked mushroom reuben was incredible (altho it COULD HAVE USED SOME MORE SHROOMS - THIS IS THE ONLY REASON I 'M NOT GIVING 5 STARS), and the husband said it was the best pastrami since katz in nyc.
author: Kim Y.

description: pastrami tasted awesome and tender..  great flavor and texture.  this was the little stall at the ferry bldg.  for more variety, go to their store in the mission.
author: Frances H.

description: My friends and I had been looking forward to going to Wise Sons for over a month but were incredibly disappointed when we made it there last weekend.  As a New York Jew living in SF, I assumed there would be knishes, real kosher pickles, big New York bagels and other traditional food on the menu.  The menu was minimal and the food was very greasy. I made the mistake of ordering shtetel toast and my friend ordered corn beef hash that looked like pastrami. We both got sick afterwards. Also, even though the restaurant is only open for a few hours each time, all the items on the menu aren't available until 11am.  This disappointed my friend who really wanted a cornbeef sandwich but couldn't order it because it wasn't exactly 11am.  For a real New York Jewish Deli experience, I'd suggest going elsewhere.
author: Marla S.

description: Being a jewish gal from NY, Wise Sons was just ok.  Food was good but the portions were way too small, especially the chopped liver.  $7.00 for a tiny portion that didn't really cover the 4 slices of rye bread.  We got there late so some of the items on the menu were sold out.  I will have to come earlier.  I'm willing to give the place another try but they need to either adjust prices or start serving larger portions.
author: Reuben K.

description: Wise Sons catered our fundraiser and they were a huge hit!  The food lasted seconds (as opposed to bad caterers, who's food just sits out).  One girl said about their pastrami "Holy sh*t! It's melting in my mouth."  Go to their pop up restaurant or have them cater your next event.  You won't regret  it.
author: Mike A.

description: Had the Pastrami on rye (homemade, I believe) at SF Street Food Fest and was blown out of the water....then got to have their lox and chicken liver on Beauty's Bagels at Eat Real Oakland and was, yet again, in love.  Wise Sons is easily the best old-school deli style food I've had this side of the MIssissippi!
author: B H.

description: don't miss this place!  the pastrami is out of this world and the rye bread is the best ever!    i'll be there again...and again.  worth every minute of the wait.
author: Ronnie W.
